Billion-dollar disaster events—that is, extreme weather events with losses that exceed $1 billion each—have been steadily increasing in the USA (Fig. 1). While there is a strong consensus that some extreme weather events have increased as a result of climate change (USGCRP 2018), the authors caution that this also reflects the increasing impacts to infrastructure systems and people (i.e., more people in an area results in more stuff being damaged when a disaster occurs). Additionally, as population grows and disparities continue, more vulnerable populations are being exposed at higher rates and severity with climatic changes. Fig. 1
Frequency of billion-dollar disaster events. Source: NOAA National Centers for Environmental Information
